results.title: The Banana! very simple yet so delicious...
results.material_description: digital screen recording of Amauryguichon's tiktok post
results.brief_description: The extraordinary popularity of videos on social media that show food being prepared in short snappy close ups gives credence to the screenwriting cliche “show it don’t say it”. There’s a sensory, hypnotic satisfaction in watching someone make a simple sandwich, or in the case of Amaury Guichon, an impossibly complicated confection.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

The extraordinary popularity of videos on social media that show food being prepared in short snappy close ups gives credence to the screenwriting cliché “show it, don’t say it”. There’s a sensory, hypnotic satisfaction in watching someone make a simple sandwich, or in the case of Amaury Guichon, an impossibly complicated confection.
description_for_label: The extraordinary popularity of videos on social media that show food being prepared in short snappy close ups gives credence to the screenwriting cliché “show it, don’t say it”. There’s a sensory, hypnotic satisfaction in watching someone make a simple sandwich, or in the case of Amaury Guichon, an impossibly complicated confection.

results.title: Vitaphone disc, "Wall Street", reel two
results.brief_description: Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. Vitaphone was the last major analog sound-on-disc system and the only one which was widely used and commercially successful.
results.description: Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:05:00 a child falling over as he kicks a football in a field
00:05:54:00 two children throw a fully clothed person into a swimming pool
00:08:35:00 slow-motion of three children running and jumping into a pool together
00:19:40:00 footage of child water skiing with Sorrento foreshore and the Continental Hotel in the background

Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

results.title: Just a story
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor, Tony Paice, Barbara Boyd-Anderson and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: An attempt to show that storytelling is not just part of literature but is part of the everyday world around us and the ways in which we relate to each other. Demonstrates that our own experiences provide a rich source of information which may be drawn upon for the writing of stories.

results.title: Fire of the land (A) [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: This beautifully written, produced and directed documentary by AFTRS student Valerie Bichard encapsulates the emotions and determination of a group of Aboriginal Australians seeking peace and justice in their campaign for Sovereign Rights. Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.
description_for_label: This beautifully written, produced and directed documentary by AFTRS student Valerie Bichard encapsulates the emotions and determination of a group of Aboriginal Australians seeking peace and justice in their campaign for Sovereign Rights. Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.

results.title: Acquiring a taste for Raffaella
results.creator_credit: Sandra Lepore, Fotini Manikakis and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The onset of menstruation leads to a curious mix of events when Raffaella shares the news with her traditional Italian Aunt. Together they make some special Italian love biscuits, “biscotti di amore”, with a secret ingredient intimately linked with Raffaella’s menarche. When the object of her affections tastes the love biscuits, surprisingly, he asks for the recipe.
